DOC.HEAD: Marchers in Leipzig Hold Vigil for Victims of Stalin
Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to include other demonstrations; picks up 7th `Recent Monday'
DOC.TEXT: Pro-democracy activists who had marched noisily each week since early fall set aside bullhorns and banners Monday night for a silent vigil to honor the victims of Stalin. An estimated 200,000 people took part. Many carried candles through the darkened winter streets around Karl Marx Platz for 15 minutes after a memorial service for those mistreated during what now is called ``the intolerance of the past.'' In September and early October, reformers were beaten and jailed for taking part in protests. ADN, the official news agency, put the crowd at more than 100,000, but an Associated Press reporter in Leipzig estimated the total at 200,000. Demonstrations also were reported in other East German cities. ADN said about 30,000 people marched through Karl-Marx-Stadt, at first silently but then with growing chants of ``Germany, United Fatherland!'' At Halle, opposition speakers were booed when they spoke against reunification, the agency said. It did not say how many people demonstrated. Several hundred candle-bearing demonstrators marched silently through central East Berlin to commemorate victims of Stalinism and about 3,000 people demonstrated for a clean environment in Schwerin, it said. Leipzig church leaders and protest organizers had asked demonstrators to be silent this week, and most marchers honored the call for a solemn memorial. Recent Monday night protests aimed at keeping pressure on the Communist-dominated government for more democratic change escalated into shouting matches between supporters of saving a sovereign East Germany and a growing minority seeking reunification with West Germany. Isolated groups of reunification advocates disrupted the silent march at times with shouts of ``Germany, United Fatherland.'' But they were quickly hushed by others who whistled their disapproval or implored them to cease chanting. There were no speeches by organizers at the march, another break with a tradition that has made the Leipzig event a forum for airing grievances and proposals. A few signs on the march route expressed solidarity with pro-democracy movements in other East European nations, especially in hard-line Romania. ``Freedom also for Romania,'' declared one sign. The discipline exhibited by most marchers was likely a result of leaflets distributed in advance of the event by Leipzig conductor Kurt Masur, a respected leader of the reform effort. ``The whole of Europe hopes along with us that the future Leipzig Monday demonstrations after Jan. 8 will continue peacefully as has been the case until now, and that the great idea of a united Europe can become reality,'' Masur wrote. ``We Germans will in this way naturally grow together and retain the trust of our neighbors.'' Activists have decided against holding protests on the next two Mondays because of the Christmas and New Year's holidays. Despite the appeals, about 200 participants tried to stir up the gathering. ``Free elections'' and ``One United Germany'' were among the political slogans hoisted by those who broke the silence. Some people in the crowd said they suspected the ultra-rightist West German Republicans party had infiltrated the marches to raise the issue of reunification. A young student from Dresden said she had been fearful of a confrontation, as the demonstration last Monday was ``a little too aggressive.'' ``I was really afraid, but I'm very glad that this went off so peacefully,'' said the woman, who did not give her name. Worries about a turn toward violence and a rift in the reform movement mounted after last week's demonstration reached a fever pitch, but there were no reports of incidents Monday. The rally's exceptional solemnity was not expected to dampen popular sentiment for reunification. ``It would all have been in vain if we don`t become a unified fatherland again,'' one elderly demonstrator told West Germany`s ZDF television network. ``I am for a unified Germany. I am prepared to wait, but I cannot wait too long,'' said another, younger participant. Leipzig was a hotbed of the democratic movement that forced East Germany's Communist leaders to open the borders Nov. 9 and relinquish much of their power. Among the reasons for Leipzig's role are a strong church movement that served as rallying point for democracy activists when authorities still had tight control over dissent, and the serious deterioration of the city.
